fields.content:
In the first two weeks, you will have a homeroom session to LEARN ABOUT 8th PERIOD SIGN UP AND ATTENDANCE POLICIES. I want to alert you to some significant changes to 8th period Lost and Found. First, we changed the name to Administrative Detention.  Second, we moved to a quarter based system. Administrative Detention remains a double block activity for students with unexcused (uncleared) 8th period absences.  Periodically each quarter, a report of 8th period unexcused absences is run, and following the criteria below, students will be assigned to Administrative Detention during 8th period. 

·         If a student gets 2 or more absences in any QUARTER, they will be assigned to Administrative Detention (AD)
·         If a student gets any additional absences in the SAME quarter after attending AD that quarter, they will be assigned to the next Administrative Detention.

Students will receive an email at their TJ email address letting them know and giving them a deadline to fix any mistakes with their teacher(s).  If the absences are not cleared in time, the student will be assigned to a double block of Detention.  Students may not be excused from Detention for any reason and failure to show up for the whole period will result in a referral to the grade level administrator.

While assignment to AD is now based upon your quarterly attendance, absences are recorded for the year and DO NOT disappear after attending Administrative Detention.  Yearly totals are used for referrals (as outlined below), assigning leadership, mentorship, parking and other privileges.  

PLEASE NOTE: Students will get referred to an Assistant Principal (for possible additional consequences and/or Saturday detention) if any of the following apply:

-      failure to show up for the detention period

-      getting 5 or more absences in any quarter

-      getting assigned to 3 Administrative Detentions in the year

-      getting 10 or more absences in the year

If you have any questions, please come see us in the 8th period office.
fields.author: Joan Burch
fields.title: NEW Administrative Detention POLICY (formerly Lost and Found):

Hot tips! Label the inside of your textbooks with “your name” AND “2014-15” so that our community can try to get them back to you if they get mislaid. (You don’t want to face the $$ fine if it never turns up!) ALSO, put a file onto your flashdrive with this file name: “YOUR NAME’s FLASH DRIVE” AND try to label the outside of it with a sharpie or metallic pen ( the librarians have one!) Where is our lost and found this year? It depends upon the object.
  • All BOOKS go to the library's computer lab room 242B. (Sometimes binders and school papers go there, too.)
  • Precious objects such as flash drives, eyeglasses and jewelry go to the security office.
  • Everything else like found clothing, lunch bags, and water bottles go into the bins inside Gym 2.

fields.content:
TJHSST ACTIVITY FAIR:  Sept. 15, 2014 - during B Block GYM 2
CLUB REPS, please read the following information carefully.
Set Up:  Set up will be permitted during the break from 2:55 to 3:10 only.  Students must have checked in at the door to gym 2 to get a pass.  REPS must be pre-registered for the Activities Fair through the Eighth Period Office to participate as a student representative & do set up.  No other students will be permitted.

Representatives:  Only the representatives whose names were provided to us will be allowed into the fair.  Please be mindful not to bring too many props as space is tight—you will be given 4 ft of table space!   Display boards/table top materials are best.

 During the fair:

  1. FOOD/DRINKS:  No drinks are allowed. You may only give away individually wrapped candy or vegetables to entice new club members.  Make sure trash from giveaways ends up in the trash cans!
  2. MUSIC:  Keep the volume down and be considerate.  If your music is too loud, you will be asked to turn it down or OFF!  
  3. HANDOUTS:  Handouts may be distributed from your booth only.  Don’t leave your assigned area to walk around advertising.
  4. POWER: You will not be allowed to use electricity; make sure you have batteries or a charge, no exceptions.
  5. CLEAN UP:  You are responsible for cleaning your table and the floor that is around your table before you exit the gym. 

 Thank you from ~ The Eighth Period Office!

fields.content:
In the next few weeks we will be opening up new spaces for learning and teaching here at TJ, but we need your help first!  When the new building is complete we will have a total of 14 commons areas.  As a thank you for patiently enduring the construction process we have decided to let you, the current students and faculty of TJ, name these spaces.  

Each commons will be named after pioneers in their respective fields.  These “pioneers” could be from any country, from any profession, and from any century.  We want you to choose the name of someone you admire and believe changed the world we live in for the better and should be honored here at TJ as a result.  Choose the name of someone who befits the grandeur of the new building and innovativeness that we hope to match within these walls.  

Click here to nominate a pioneer

Here’s the plan:

Collection of this poll ends 8am on Monday 10/20.  Then a committee (including students, faculty, and admin) will whittle down this list to create a final voting list of 30 names.  Then we will send it back to you, the students and faculty, for the final selection of 14 names with voting ending on Oct. 31.  Each space will then be assigned one of the 14 names.  

Click here to nominate a pioneer


Thanks for participating!

fields.content:
Students: 

Thank you for nominating hundreds of names for our TJ commons.  From this list of pioneers in various fields a committee of students, teachers, and administrators has narrowed the list down to the final 30 pioneers who represent various fields of study, historical time periods, and backgrounds.  What each of these selections have in common is that they are pioneers in their fields and demonstrate the ingenuity and innovativeness that we strive for here at TJ.  

Please vote for the 14 pioneers you would like for us to name TJ commons spaces after.  Each student and faculty member will be allowed to submit their top 14 list only once.  Voting will end on Oct. 31 at noon and the announcement of the winners will be made on the first week of November.

Voting will be done through your fcpsschools.net Google Account.  Remember this is your Student ID Number with @fcpsschools.net at the end.  If you are having problems accessing your account please see Mrs. Applin or Mrs. Carpenter in the Library or Mrs. Tecuci in room 110 for help.  All students have a FCPS Google Account access.

VOTE HERE

The Nominees

JOHN BARDEEN 

He was an American physicist and electrical engineer and the only person to have won the Nobel Prize in Physics twice. The transistor revolutionized the electronics industry, allowing the Information Age to occur, and made possible the development of almost every modern electronic device, from telephones to computers to missiles. Bardeen's developments in superconductivity, which won him his second Nobel, are used in Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (NMR) or its medical sub-tool magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

RACHEL CARSON

She was a writer, scientist, and ecologist who wrote many literary works to inform the public about nature, such as the book Silent Spring, in which she wrote about the dangerous effects of pesticides and tried to convince people to view the world in a different perspective. In 1963, she testified in front of Congress and called for policies to protect human health and the environment. She should be honored at TJ because she helped start the environmental revolution and changed the way we look at our world.

GEORGE WASHINGTON CARVER

African-American inventor who had the highest number of patents at his time solely for the benefit of food consumption. He was a pioneer in all fields of science: chemistry, physics, botany and biology.

VINT CERF 

He is a 'father of the Internet,' and, along with Bob Khan, created TCP/IP, the Transmission Control and Internet Protocols, the basis of the technology which would help create the Internet. He has connections to TJHSST (his son attended TJ) and has won numerous awards including the National Medal of Technology, the Turing Award, and the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

JACQUES COUSTEAU 

He once described a scientist as 'a curious man looking through a keyhole, the keyhole of nature, trying to know what's going on.' Cousteau was passionate about the sea, and I admire him for using his talents in writing and film-making to draw much-needed attention to ocean conservation.

MARIE CURIE 

She is an exemplar and a pioneer for not only science, but also women in science. As the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the first person-- and only woman-- to win the Nobel Prize twice, she risked her life to bring forth breakthrough theories on radioactivity (a term she coined) and would ultimately pass away due to her extensive exposure to radiation, the epitome of scientific dedication until the end.

LEONARDO DA VINCI 

The definition of a Renaissance man, da Vinci was not only famous for his art, but also for his work with anatomy, engineering, geology, botany, cartography, architecture, music, and mathematics.  I can think of no better person to represent the various interests that can be found at TJ.

CHARLES DARWIN 

Without Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection, biology is just a collection of facts without a unifying theory. As Theodosius Dobzhansky said in his 1973 essay: 'Nothing in Biology Makes Sense Except in the Light of Evolution'.


ALBERT EINSTEIN 

Einstein was above everyone else in that he didn't simply accept other scientists' theories. After discovering that the speed of light remains constant, he spent years researching its correlations with speed and mass and eventually reached a breakthrough where he discovered relativity.

LEONHARD EULER 

He and Carl Friedrich Gauss vie for the title of greatest mathematician of all time. Euler contributed more than any other person to the field of mechanics (both fluid and solid).

MICHAEL FARADAY

Michael Faraday displayed the true spirit of science even though he lacked a formal education. Faraday made many important discoveries about electricity, which helped create the world we live in today. I think we should name our commons the 'Faraday Commons' to honor this genius who so truly deserves it.

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN 

Franklin was a self-made entrepreneur, turned renaissance man, turned patriot, who, embraced the best scientific and political elements of the Enlightenment.  His wisdom and cunning helped give birth to the United States as a society that made real the fantasy of popular government in an organic form that would facilitate, however slowly, the incubation and evolution of ideas such as justice and scientific advancement.

ROSALIND FRANKLIN 

Though Franklin was instrumental in the discovery of DNA's structure, she received no credit for it at the time. Even now, she is frequently excluded from the 'Watson and Crick' narrative. I think it's important that we recognize the contributions of those often left out of lists of scientific pioneers and that we include female scientists and Rosalind Franklin fulfills both of those criteria.

GALILEO GALLILEI 

The father of modern astronomy who supported the advancement of science against the persecution of the church (there were widely different belief systems in the early 17th century).

MAHATMA GANDHI 

Despite the fact that Gandhi was an extremely well educated lawyer, he was a pioneer in the field of non-violent social activism. He is a reminder to us all that we must use our education to create a difference in the world, and due to the fact that we are recieving a world-class education it is our duty to become the leaders of tomorrow and take the baton to be the next Gandhis, because there is so much change that still needs to occur.

CARL FRIEDRICH GAUSS 

His contemporaries called him princeps mathematicorum, prince of mathematics. We can call a mere lobby by his name.

GRACE HOPPER

As a female pioneer in the computing field, Rear Admiral Dr. Grace Murray Hopper was a remarkable woman who contributed to the transition from primitive programming techniques to the use of sophisticated compilers.  A mathematician, military officer, and computer scientist, she is an amazing role model for women.  Her belief that that the statement 'we've always done it that way' is not necessarily a good reason to continue to follow the status quo is an ideal that could inspire TJ students for many years to come.

MAE JEMISON

A physician who became the first female African American astronaut and first black women to go into space.

FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT

Innovative American Architect.

JOHN LOCKE 

Locke thought of ideas that incredibly affected the founding of the US. His theories on government and the social contract were vital to Thomas Jefferson when he wrote the Declaration of Independence.

THURGOOD MARSHALL

Lawyer-Changed history in 1954 when he successfully argued Brown vs. the Board of Education before the Supreme Court. Also played huge role in NAACP cases and was selected as first African-American Supreme Court Justice.

ISAAC NEWTON

All TJ students will grow to hate this guy for inventing two of the most terrifying things ever: calculus and physics. It is both fitting and hilarious that Newton's name be integrated within the very foundation of TJ.

ALFRED NOBEL

Chemist who invented dynamite, and then dedicated his fortune to the Nobel Prizes out of remorse. A reminder to students of the power of knowledge to heal and to destroy.

JACKIE ROBINSON 

Jackie Robinson was the first black player in the Major Baseball League. His entry faced tremendous turmoil in the 40s from 'separate but equal' advocates, yet his participation illustrated good players, regardless of race, could enhance professional sports.

DAVID SAWYER 

Dr. Sawyer was the essential person who worked with business, government, and community organizations to launch TJHSST in 1984. In only 30 years, the school has maintained an international prominence, thanks to his vision and determination as assistant superintendent in Fairfax County Public Schools.

NIKOLA TESLA 

Nikola Tesla is a name forgotten in history for no apparent reason even after his research in Alternating Current, Radio, and Energy Transmission. An immigrant undaunted by failing mental conditions, Tesla exemplifies the classic 'rags-to-riches' tale, going from digging ditches at $2 a day to powering the World's Fair at Niagara Falls.

HENRY DAVID THOREAU 

A scientist, a philosopher, and the inspiration for the 'Civil Disobedience' of Martin Luther King, Thoreau challenges conformity and embodies the questioning spirit we hope TJ represents.  As he stated in his letter to a friend, H.G.O. Blake, on 16 November 1857: “It is not enough to be industrious; so are the ants. What are you industrious about?”

ALAN TURING

Turing is widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence. He provided formal definitions for the concepts of algorithm and computation, and conceived the 'Turing Machine' which helped win WWII.

ORVILLE AND WILBUR WRIGHT 

The world has changed as a result of flying aircraft. The Wright brothers not only invented through experimentation, but they were daring enough to test the prototype vehicles themselves. Great role models for inquiry at Jefferson.

MALALA YOUSAFZAI

Malala Yousafzai is a Pakistani activist for female education and the youngest-ever Nobel Prize recipient.

VOTE HERE

Hi everyone! The One Question steering committee is looking for new members to join and help with upcoming activities related to the One Question. 


The One Question this year is: “How can we strive to discover and pursue our own passions despite societal norms and external pressures that would compromise our aspirations and dissuade us from pursuing them?”

The One Question steering committee is brainstorming ways to make this question more relevant and exciting to the TJ community, so participation and input would be fantastic! fields.content: Interested in computer science? World languages? Puzzles? If so, then the NACLO competition may just be for you. The North American Computational Linguistic Olympiad is a contest in which high-school students solve linguistic puzzles. In solving these puzzles, students learn about the diversity and consistency of language, while exercising logic skills. No prior knowledge of linguistics or second languages is necessary. Professionals in linguistics, computational linguistics and language technologies use dozens of languages to create engaging problems that represent cutting edge issues in their fields. The competition has attracted top students to study and work in those same fields. It is truly an opportunity for young people to experience a taste of natural-language processing in the 21st century. The first round contest will take place on January 29. Practices will be held on Fridays starting this week during B-block in T19. Sign up for NACLO practice to see what the fun is all about! (You can still participate if you can’t come to the practices, email Miss Galanos (rgalanos@fcps.edu) for details.

fields.content:
Dear Class of 2016:

The senior research application materials are available in the Blackboard site - TJHSST Senior Research Lab Application Site - Class of 2016. If you do not have access to this Blackboard site, please email bjkennedy@fcps.edu with your ID number and explain that you do not have access to the Blackboard site - TJHSST Senior Research Lab Application Site - Class of 2016

Review these materials and the provided timeline for this process. It would be to your advantage to begin now to develop research ideas and areas of interest so that you are ready for the ONLINE application due date (no later than Monday, December 15, 2014, 4:00 PM).

Please review all of these documents prior to November 23, 2014 so you are ready for the 'Counselor Group' meeting on December 1. On this date, you will attend a Junior Class Counselor Group Meeting session during which the Senior Research Lab Application process will be explained by the Research Lab Directors and questions related to the application process shall also be addressed.

In order to complete the online application, students MUST activate their FCPS Google account – this must be done in the Library or with a current teacher. Further instructions for this are provided within the application instructions packet posted in Blackboard.  THIS WAS SUPPOSED TO BE DONE IN HOMEROOM in early-September.

Research lab project idea consultation sessions will occur 8th periods on December 3 and 5, 2014 during which overviews of specific labs will be provided. You are expected to attend at least two of these 15-minute sessions to learn about the labs and make final determinations based on your intended senior year research interests. Questions related to a specific lab shall be addressed during these research lab project idea consultation sessions. Please read the attached instructions for how to sign up for the 8th period offerings (they are slightly different than the normal A and B blocks). Do this early do get your preferred times and sessions.

Please review each of the documents listed below, found within the "Application Info" folder.

• Class of 2015 - Senior Research Application (must complete and submit responses online, no hardcopy submission)
• Class of 2016 - Senior Research - Prerequisite Matrix
• Lab Visit Schedule (sign up via 8th period sign ups). Sessions will also be available for Mentorship.
• Lab Selection Online Application (due Dec 15, 4:00 PM); see respective folder in site. [ This will be made available in the very near future, but draft responses can be worked on in the version posted within Blackboard].

** In mid-December, there will be separate sessions to learn more about Summer Research Opportunities so stay tuned and plan ahead to attend one of these.

In the meantime, between now and the December lab sessions, students are encouraged to begin researching and developing ideas for their top lab choices so you have more time to complete the application. Students must also activate their FCPS Google account, for which opportunities have been explained via school announcements. This was supposed to be done in Homeroom at the start of the school so if needed, please ask your HR teacher to assist.

Questions? Please see Mrs. Hennig or Mr. Hannum, your counselor – or address them during the December sessions.

fields.content:
The BYOD wireless system, FCPS Onboard, is used solely for device registration, not device management and, therefore, doesn’t provide FCPS the capability to monitor activities on BYOD devices. The purpose of the system is to provide an easy-to-use mechanism to register BYOD devices to allow students and employees the ability to use their own device on the FCPS enterprise wireless network and Internet.

During the registration process, information such as IP address and MAC address are collected and logged. This information would be used to locate a device if it is misplaced or if inappropriate activity, in possible violation of the Acceptable Use Policy (AUP), was traced back to a particular device on the network. It is not the intention of FCPS to actively manage, monitor or access BYOD devices. In situations where there is a potential AUP violation, FCPS does reserve the right to investigate all devices and activities on the FCPS network, including BYOD devices, to determine if any wrongdoing occurred.

More information about the FCPS BYOD program can be found at http://www.fcps.edu/it/byod/index.shtml.

fields.content:
During the holiday season, you may feel compelled to give a staff member a thoughtful token of appreciation. Here are some tips:

1.     Nothing – it’s not expected; OR

2.     Talk to the custodians, thank them for their work, and express your interest to help them pick up at the end of lunch; OR

3.     Write a card to a teacher expressing how much you enjoy learning in class and how that teacher has inspired you; OR

4.     Write a card expressing a New Year’s resolution to do better in that class because you really care about your intellectual growth and plan to go in for extra help starting in 2015; OR

5.     Make a “smart snack” because staff try to be healthy; OR

6.     Offer a modest gift valued at or under $25 (anything more places teachers in an ethical dilemma); OR

7.     Provide desired supplies for their classroom/work area

Thank you for your kindness and care for our staff.  Happy Holidays!
fields.author: Evan Glazer
fields.title: Holiday Gift Ideas - Student to Teacher

fields.content:
During the holiday season, you may feel compelled to give a parent a thoughtful token of appreciation. Here are some tips:

1.     Talk to them.  They love you and will get excited to hear about your aspirations and interests.

2.     Avoid school work.  They want to know you can take a break.

3.     Put away your Smartphone when you are in the same room as them.  They will think you are paying attention to them, which makes them feel important.

4.     Participate in awkward family photos (see below).  They will find it exciting.

Thank you for your kindness to your parents.  Happy Holidays!
fields.author: Evan Glazer
fields.title: Holiday Gift Ideas - Student to Parent

fields.content:
During the holiday season, you may feel compelled to give a friend a thoughtful token of appreciation.  Here are some tips:

1.     “Smart Snacks” Nutrition Guidelines need not apply as long as you don't sell them – these are called unsmart snacks.

2.     You are not smart to leave unsmart snacks unattended – be smart to use the lower level lockable cubbies, if necessary, to protect precious unsmartness.

3.     You are not smart to take unattended unsmart snacks that are not intended for you.

4.     You are smart to dispose unsmart snacks that have fallen and can't get up.

Thank you for being smart to take care of our school and each other.  Happy Holidays!
fields.author: Evan Glazer
fields.title: Holiday Gift Ideas - Student to Student

fields.content:
Most of the privacy concerns regarding FCPSonboard are related to the XpressConnect app. Here’s a few things you may want to know about this app:

  • The app is used to download a certificate that authenticates your FCPS credentials and puts you on the correct wireless network. Once you’ve installed the certificate, you no longer need the app and you can and delete it.
  • You have to reset your FCPS password every school year (this also resets your FCPS GAE password). You also have to renew the certificate every school year with your new credentials. Thus, after you reset your FCPS password each school year, you will also need to re-join FCPSonboard and re-download the XpressConnect app to reinstall the certificate. So you only need to have the app on your phone for a few minutes once every school year. Once the certificate is installed, you can delete XpressConnect.
  • This app is not downloaded on iOS devices-they have a different method of installing the certificate

If you need help connecting your device to the WiFi, please see Ms. Tecuci in room 14.

fields.content:
Happy Holidays, TJ! On December 17th, Wednesday A AND B Block, TJTED will be hosting a reception/party (with food!) and a speaker.

Justin Schuster, a current Senior at Yale University, will speak to us about his experiences in pursuing Global Affairs and Middle Eastern Studies at Yale, including his travels to over 16 countries in the past 2 years. He has worked in the Middle East and has been evacuated from Egypt during the revolution. He coordinates Yale's international Model UN conferences, and has run conferences in Prague, Guangzhou, Beijing, Egypt, and nearly in North Korea! Justin is also the Editor-In-Chief of Yale's The Politic, and oversaw the journal's largest project so far - Diplomatic Discourse, an interview series with over 100 U.S. Ambassadors from around the world. 

For those interested in a career in diplomacy/ambassadorship, Justin also recently passed the Foreign Service Officer Test, and is very familiar with the process of entering the FS. 

This is not only a chance to invite friends and hang out before Break, but also to listen to an accomplished student leader from one of the most prestigious universities in the nation. We couldn't be more excited to host him, and everyone is invited to attend - don't miss it!

fields.content:
A 2015 Brain Bee qualifying exam for TJ students will be offered on January 9, (A and B blocks, 90 minutes). Space is limited. The test is hard. This qualifier is designed to identify the top two candidates that will advance to the DC Regional Brain Bee, and possibly the national competition. Any student wishing to sign up for the TJ qualifier should be highly motivated to both win at the DC Regional Bee and study for and attend the national competition, which has a different format. See the information below to know more about the Brain Bee regional and national competitions.

The DC Regional Brain Bee is a live neuroscience competition for high school students. It is free to participate. The 2015 DC bee will take place on February 10 from 5-8pm.

The Brain Bee is a global contest that seeks to inspire students to learn more about the brain and pursue science-related careers. The DC Regional Brain Bee is open to students in grades 9–12 who attend home or high schools in Washington, DC, southern Maryland, and northern Virginia. Each school may send up to two students to the competition.

All questions used during the Bee will be taken from the Brain Facts book, which can be downloaded for free at BrainFacts.org/book. The first place winner will receive a cash prize of $250 and will be eligible to compete in the US National Brain Bee.
fields.author: James Woglom
fields.title: 2015 Brain Bee

fields.content: It’s time for the NACLO! The North American Computational Linguistic Olympiad is a contest in which high-school students solve linguistic puzzles. In solving these puzzles, students learn about the diversity and consistency of language, while exercising logic skills. No prior knowledge of linguistics or second languages is necessary. Professionals in linguistics, computational linguistics, and language technologies use dozens of languages to create engaging problems that represent cutting edge issues in their fields. The competition has attracted top students to study and work in those same fields. It is truly an opportunity for young people to experience a taste of natural-language processing in the 21st century. The first round contest will take place on Thursday, January 29 from 10am-2pm (there are no semester exams scheduled that day). To sign up, visit http://bit.ly/NACLO no later than Friday, January 23. There is no cost to participate. A practice will be held on Friday. January 9 in T20 during B Block. You can still sign up for the contest if you can’t come to the practice. Email Miss Galanos (rgalanos@fcps.edu) for details.
fields.author: James Woglom
fields.title: North American Computational Linguistic Olympiad

fields.content:
The list for 8th period detention is being created this week! PLEASE CLEAR YOUR ABSENCES. To be removed you must clear your 8th period absences BEFORE 4pm on Friday, February 13 . Many from January may still be cleared. How?

It's simple: click on the absence link from your home page, print the page and ask the teacher to sign off that you were there -- be sure to include your name, your ID, the name of the activity that you attended. Return the sheet to room 231 and you're done!

To keep from getting an absence:

  • Go to the activity that you chose -- and don't leave!
  • Make sure your teacher knows you are there.
  • DO NOT sign the bottom of a roster or attendance sheet. These names are not included in attendance and will result in an absence.
  • Don't ask a substitute to 'call you in', they can't! Absences in activities with a substitute teacher cannot be cleared!
  • Turn in your pass to the sponsor as soon as you arrive!
  • QUESTIONS? See Mrs. Burch or Mrs. Lauducci in the 8th period office (room 231)

fields.content:
The USA Biology Olympiad Open Exam is scheduled for Wednesday, February 11, 2015 in Gym 2.

All participants previously signed up for this restricted activity must be settled and ready to start by the beginning of A block. As soon as you arrive, take a seat facing forward and stay seated.

To have your exam graded by the CEE, you MUST do the following:

  Use #2 pencils; Bring several sharpened, with good erasers.

  Complete a Student Certificate which will be provided.

  Complete ALL personal information on your scantron.

  Provide the proper CEE ID (NOT FCPS SID) on your scantron.

o Note that you will need to BRING your CEE ID; it will not be provided for you.

  Never use an electronic device.

  Do not leave your seat once the examination process has begun, until the time you are dismissed, even if you finish early.

  Follow instructions given on exam day, and

  Turn in all your paperwork AS DIRECTED.

Bring a watch if you are concerned about time management.

No additional time will be given for erasing, bubbling in, writing your name, etc. When the exam time runs out, you will be asked to turn in your paperwork immediately. Follow the instructions!

Reminder: The exam will occur during both A and B blocks.

You are expected to attend at least two of these 15-minute sessions to learn about the labs and also learn about necessary prerequisite course requirements for your intended senior year research lab interests. For these, you will sign up using the 8th period sign ups BUT for combinations of C & D and/or E &F Blocks (instead of A or B). You must do combinations of C & D or E & F to visit two or four different sessions, and can do this on each Wednesday and Friday enabling you to visit in total up to eight different sessions.

fields.content:
Students,

We have had some major issues in our computer labs recently and wanted to remind all of you about computer lab etiquette.  The most important thing that you should note is that you should not unplug mice or keyboards to use with your personal laptops when in labs.  There has been theft of computer equipment and this should not occur at a place like TJ.  Equipment shouldn’t require constantly reconnecting unplugged or moved equipment and/or replacing missing mice and keyboards.  Below is a list of computer lab etiquette that if followed will save our Tech Team hundreds of hours spent each school year that they spend replacing, repairing, and cleaning up after student messes.  They could be spending this time updating computers and providing new innovative technology to students, but sadly much of it is spent doing lab maintenance and clean up.   Thanks for your attention to this.

Computer Lab Etiquette:

  • Do not unplug computer equipment.  If you accidentally unplug something, please plug it back in.
  • Do not remove the mouse or keyboard from the computer.
  • Do not leave trash behind.
  • No eating or drinking.
  • Report any computer problems to the teacher.
fields.author: Scott Campbell
fields.title: Computer Lab Etiquette

  • Churchill Road Elementary School (McLean): Tuesday, March 10 is Family Science Night from 5-9 p.m. Come and help demonstrate the Museum Without Walls science exhibits. Pizza dinner will be provided! 
  • Liberty Elementary School (South Riding): Participate in STEMmerday on March 14.  Assist adults with hands-on STEM activities for elementary school students.  This is a really big event from 9am-3pm, however you can work in 3 hour shifts. 
  • Marshall Road Elementary (Vienna): Run booths at STEM Night (Fri, April 24, 6-9PM), an evening dedicated to inspiring in the kids a passion for STEM. Pizza will be provided to all volunteers!
  • Fox Mill Elementary School (Herndon): Students needed for Science Fair judging on April14th and 15th between 5:30pm - 7 pm.
  • Bailey's Upper Elementary School (Falls Church): May 26 is Mobile Lab Family Science Night from 5:00-8:30p.m. Come and help demonstrate the Children's Science Center exhibits.

Email stembassadors@tjhsst.edu if you would like to participate in one of these service activities.  More info about STEMbassadors

fields.content:
TJTED will be hosting a special speaker this Friday, March 13th, during B Block in the College and Career Center! Yale Global Health Professor, Richard Skolnik, will be focusing his talk on the root causes of sickness, disability, and mortality, how this happens, and what we can do to address these issues effectively. This is a talk for everyone, whether you're looking to have a deeper understanding of public health, or would like a proper introduction/foundation. 

Sign up on Intranet now, before space fills up! As always, there will be time for Q&A afterward, so bring any questions you may have!

During his 25 years working with the World Bank, Skolnik worked primarily on education, health, nutrition, and population in low-income countries in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia. He was previously also the Director of the Harvard School of Public Health PEPFAR program for AIDS treatment in Africa. 

More info on the speaker: 

http://publichealth.yale.edu/people/richard_skolnik-2.profile

http://r4d.org/experts/richard-skolnik
fields.author: Adam Wong
fields.title: INTERESTED IN GLOBAL HEALTH OR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT?
